user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_bd_sync:
```c
static int lfs_bd_sync(lfs_t *lfs,
        lfs_cache_t *pcache, lfs_cache_t *rcache, bool validate) {
    lfs_cache_drop(lfs, rcache);

    int err = lfs_bd_flush(lfs, pcache, rcache, validate);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    err = lfs->cfg->sync(lfs->cfg);
    LFS_ASSERT(err <= 0);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_bd_sync:
static inline void lfs_cache_drop(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_cache_t *rcache) {
    // do not zero, cheaper if cache is readonly or only going to be
    // written with identical data (during relocates)
    (void)lfs;
    rcache->block = LFS_BLOCK_NULL;
}
...
static int lfs_bd_flush(lfs_t *lfs,
        lfs_cache_t *pcache, lfs_cache_t *rcache, bool validate) {
    if (pcache->block != LFS_BLOCK_NULL && pcache->block != LFS_BLOCK_INLINE) {
        LFS_ASSERT(pcache->block < lfs->block_count);
        lfs_size_t diff = lfs_alignup(pcache->size, lfs->cfg->prog_size);
        int err = lfs->cfg->prog(lfs->cfg, pcache->block,
                pcache->off, pcache->buffer, diff);
        LFS_ASSERT(err <= 0);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        if (validate) {
            // check data on disk
            lfs_cache_drop(lfs, rcache);
            int res = lfs_bd_cmp(lfs,
                    NULL, rcache, diff,
                    pcache->block, pcache->off, pcache->buffer, diff);
            if (res < 0) {
                return res;
            }

            if (res != LFS_CMP_EQ) {
                return LFS_ERR_CORRUPT;
            }
        }

        lfs_cache_zero(lfs, pcache);
    }

    return 0;
}
...
static int lfs_bd_cmp(lfs_t *lfs,
        const lfs_cache_t *pcache, lfs_cache_t *rcache, lfs_size_t hint,
        lfs_block_t block, lfs_off_t off,
        const void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    const uint8_t *data = buffer;
    lfs_size_t diff = 0;

    for (lfs_off_t i = 0; i < size; i += diff) {
        uint8_t dat[8];

        diff = lfs_min(size-i, sizeof(dat));
        int err = lfs_bd_read(lfs,
                pcache, rcache, hint-i,
                block, off+i, &dat, diff);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }

        int res = memcmp(dat, data + i, diff);
        if (res) {
            return res < 0 ? LFS_CMP_LT : LFS_CMP_GT;
        }
    }

    return LFS_CMP_EQ;
}
...
static inline void lfs_cache_zero(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_cache_t *pcache) {
    // zero to avoid information leak
    memset(pcache->buffer, 0xff, lfs->cfg->cache_size);
    pcache->block = LFS_BLOCK_NULL;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only the use of memcmp in lfs_bd_cmp needs investigation for Rule 21.14. No other memcmp calls exist in the provided code. The other functions (lfs_bd_sync, lfs_bd_flush, lfs_cache_drop, lfs_cache_zero) do not call memcmp or perform string comparisons (they use memset, direct assignments, or call cfg functions). lfs_bd_flush passes explicit sizes and buffers to lfs_bd_cmp (binary data length), so the memcmp usage is likely comparing raw memory, but must be reviewed to ensure it is not being used to compare null-terminated strings. No other fragments in the provided code match the rule's concern, so they need not be investigated for Rule 21.14.
